tn.text: Yahweh continues talking with Moses about dealing with Pharaoh and bringing the Hebrew people out of Egypt.

tn.ref: if you refuse to let them go, if you still keep them back
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. They will emphasize to Pharaoh what will happen if Pharaoh does this. AT: "if you continue refusing to let them go" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: then Yahweh's hand will be on your cattle
tn.text: The word "hand" here represents Yahweh's power to afflict their animals with disease. AT: "then the power of Yahweh will afflict your cattle " (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "your" here refers to all the people of Egypt who owned cattle.
Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. AT: "the cattle belonging to the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Egypt" refers to the people of Egypt. AT: "the cattle belonging to the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"set a time" or "appointed a time"

tn.ref: all the cattle of Egypt died
tn.text: This is exaggerated to emphasize the seriousness of the event. AT: "a large number of the cattle of Egypt died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Here "Egypt" refers to the people of Egypt. AT: "the cattle belonging to the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Pharaoh collected facts about the situation.
The word "behold" here shows that Pharaoh was surprised by what he saw.
Here "heart" refers to Pharaoh. AT: "he refused to change his mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
a furnace
"very small"
"to quickly appear on"

Here "heart" refers to Pharaoh. His stubborn attitude is spoken of as if his heart was hard. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:07:11|7:13]].  AT: "Yahweh caused Pharaoh to became more defiant"(See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means that even Pharaoh will be hurt by the plagues. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: I will do this so that you may know
tn.text: The word "this" refers to the plagues that Moses had just told Pharaoh about.

tn.ref: reached out with my hand and attacked you
tn.text: Here "my hand" refers to God's power. AT: "used my power to strike you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so that my name may be proclaimed throughout all the earth
tn.text: Here "my name" represents Yahweh's reputation. AT: "so that people everywhere will know I am great" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: lifting yourself up against my people
tn.text: Pharaoh's opposition to letting Israel go to worship Yahweh is spoken of as if he was raising himself up as a barrier to them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Pay attention to the important thing I am about to tell you"
"call"
"Moses said to Pharaoh"

tn.ref: spread my hands out to Yahweh
tn.text: This symbolic gesture accompanies prayer. AT: "lift up my hands and pray to Yahweh" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Honoring God involves obeying him and living in a way that shows how great he is.
This is a plant that produces fibers that can be made into linen cloth.
This is a type of grain used for making bread; also used for cattle feed.
This is a kind of wheat.

tn.ref: spread out his hands to Yahweh
tn.text: This symbolic gesture accompanies prayer. AT: "lifted up his hands toward Yahweh and prayed" (UDB) See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:09:29|9:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

Here "heart" refers to Pharaoh. His stubborn attitude is spoken of as if his heart was hard. AT: "became more defiant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "heart" refers to Pharaoh. His stubborn attitude is spoken of as if his heart was hard. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:07:11|7:13]]. AT: "Pharaoh became more defiant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
